fields.label_text:
How to Live

Author: Bobby Baker
Venue: Barbican

Set and Costume Designer
Miranda Melville

'Fill the Barbican stage with peas and make them sing and dance, was Bobby Baker's brief.

Primarily a performance artist, Bobby Baker conceived this sciart project in consultation with psychologist Richard Hallam. It was developed through collaborative workshops, often producing totally absurd ideas, but always underlined by the seriousness of the subject of mental health.

The frame work was of an imposing conference, presenting a new therapy for mental illness, illustrated through Bobby's chosen patient, a pea. To make the pea visible, video playback inevitably became integral to the show, along with her powerpoint presentation. The finale was a specially composed chorale performed by the dancing peas.'

Company: Daily Life Theatre - November 2004

Director: Palona Baloh Brown
Artist, Deviser, Performer: Bobby Baker
Set and Costume Designer: Miranda Melville
Lighting Designer: Chahine Yavroyan
Composer: Jocelyn Pook
Video and Graphics: Deborah May
Engineer/Set Builder: Simon York
Production Manager: Steve Wald

Photographer: Andrew Whittuck

COLLABORATORS STATEMENTS

BOBBY
Although I had worked with every member of this team previously, I'd never had the chance before to bring us all together for such a large scale ambitious artwork. The collaboration process has mostly felt very positive for me, and I feel this project my most successful group collaboration to date. Integration seems the best word to sum up the process and outcome.

POLONAH
The originality of so many voices worked because they listened, trusted and believed each other even in those moments of perplexity that mark all good collaborations.

CHAHINE
The realisation of Bobby's Idea was a positive and open collaborative experience. Working with a visual artist the lighting needed to evolve into the theatrical with visual gags, etc. a cross between theatre and dance in what was essentially a "conference" type setting.

DEBORAH
Blessed are the cracked for they let in the light

STEVE
It's good working with collaborators who don't feel the need to prove everything all the time.

SIMON
I would say that the pea rig is probably the most difficult thing I have ever made and certainly the most beautiful. The nature of the piece was such that it had to evolve by experiment. It could not, therefore, have been achieved without the production manager, the designer and the builder all being able to achieve a mutual understanding of the technical and aesthetic issues so that the right decisions could be made at each stage of the process.

RICHARD
As a complete novice to the theatre, I was struck that a group of anarchic individuals could work so effectively together when they had a clear goal in view.

fields.descriptive_line: Set model designed by Miranda Melville for Bobby Baker's play How to Live by Bobby Baker, Daily Life Theatre at the Barbican, London, 2004.
fields.physical_description:
[set model] Computer illustration printed on cardboard of stage plans.
[set model] Photograph printed on cardboard of many hanging rows of peas at different levels, against a blue background.
[set model] Photograph printed on cardboard of many hanging rows of peas against a red background, with purple floor.
[set model] Photograph printed on cardboard of a person dressed as a pea on a purple-lit stage.
[set model] Stage plan printed on white art board; computer illustration.
[set model] Story board printed on white art board; annotated line-drawn illustrations.
[set model] Story board printed on white art board, of annotated line-drawn illustrations.
[set model] Black card box with no top representing a proscenium stage. The floor of the stage has a layer of white card. There is a piece of white card on the back wall and two pieces of white card at angles up-stage right and left. A wide layer of sticky tape is attached to either end of the box, across the middle of the stage. Attached to the tape are many small green beads representing peas. In front of the peas, down-stage right, is a cut out of a woman in a lab coat.
[set model] Black card box with no top representing a proscenium stage. The floor of the stage has a layer of white card. There is a piece of white card on the back wall printed with a close up picture of peas. Down-stage right is a model of a red sofa, with a small green bead representing a pea on it.
[set model] Black card box with no top representing a proscenium stage. The floor of the stage has a layer of white card. There is a metal wire grid balancing over the top from which hang 35 beads on wires, painted green to represent dancing peas.
[set model] Black card box with no top representing a proscenium stage. The floor of the stage has a layer of white card. Up-stage is a piece of white card against the back wall. Down-stage is a cut out of a woman in a white lab coat standing next to a styrofoam chair with a large green ball in it, representing a pea.
[set model] Black card box with no top representing a proscenium stage. The floor of the stage has a layer of white card. Up-stage are three pieces of white card, the middle of which has an image of a woman in a white lab coat holding out her arm. Down-stage left is a small piece of white card attached by two pieces of wire to the top of the proscenium with a mid-shot image of the woman, below which is a cardboard cut out of the woman standing by a transparent plastic model lectern.
[set model] Base of black art board, with black proscenium and white set with two sets of white flats at the back and a white square with hole on the wall (designed to see a small monitor through). Up-stage left is a model television; down-stage right is a model fireplace, lamp and red sofa; down-stage left is a paper cut out of a figure by a model lectern.

fields.title: How To Live
fields.label:
How to Live

Author: Bobby Baker
Venue: Barbican

Set and Costume Designer

[set model] how to / live
[set model] how to / live
fields.public_access_description:
This is a set model designed by Miranda Melville for the production How to Live, by performance artist Bobby Baker. The production was funded by the Sciart project, funded by the Wellcome Institute, which sought to stimulate debate collaboratively between science and the arts. Baker conceived this project in consultation with psychologist Richard Hallam, with the subject matter being mental health.

Taking the framework of a conference, Baker presented a new kind of therapy for mental illness, with her patient of choice being a pea. Video playback was used to make the pea visible, with the finale being a chorale performed by dancing peas on wires.

This set model depicts the main stage performance, in S.1299:1-2010, with Baker on stage presenting a powerpoint presentation. This was originally shown through a monitor in the back of the stage set. There are also many other scenes from the performance, shown in separate parts of the model, including the dancing peas on wires, and a giant pea on an armchair. The model also includes storyboards of how the piece is presented.
fields.exhibition_history: Collaborators: UK design for performance 2003-2007 (Victoria and Albert Museum, Galleries 103 -106 21/11/2007-31/08/2008)
